WINSTORY_NAME: Cybereason: OCI - Cybersecurity, End Point Security
WINSTORY_REPS_SE: Josh.Edmond@oracle.com, Daniel.Grant@oracle.com, Ignacio.Loureiro@oracle.com, Sanjay.Basu@oracle.com, Daryn.McCool@oracle.com, Mans.Bhuller@oracle.com,Tom.Liakos@oracle.com, Jeet.Jagasia@oracle.com, Joe Corvaia@oracle.com
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS:
After evangelizing OCI to multiple Cybereason teams over the preceding eight months, Josh was finally able to secure a meeting with Cybereason’s Chief Product Office. Building on the momentum from this meeting, Josh arranged Oracle and Cybereason executives – including their Chief Revenue and Chief Customer Officers – to meet at OpenWorld 2019.   

Leveraging the ISV Accelerate framework, and highlighting GTM opportunities unmatched by Cybereason’s other public cloud providers (AWS and GCP), the Oracle team persuaded Cybereason’s leadership to evaluate OCI. The team then arranged a subsequent meeting between Safra Catz and Cybereason’s CEO, Lior Div. 

After the CEOs connected, the technical enablement process moved ahead.  This stage was made challenging by the fact that some of Cybereason’s technical teams had reservations about running on OCI.  Apprehensions, however, were dispelled in late January when six members of the Oracle technical team flew to Tel Aviv to host a series of in-depth technical workshops
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
- Many teams, one Oracle: Big deals are complex and require an entire team engaging with the partner.  To get this deal closed, Josh successfully worked with the OCI Product Management team, Oracle  IT, as well as the ISV Ecosystem Sales Consulting, ISV Business Development and Marketing teams.  Critical support also came from Oracle Legal, Rev Rec and many others.   
 
- Strong organization: Some of the complexity encountered in this deal simply came from coordinating across multiple Oracle teams… some of which were not used to working together.  However, resources were managed well and deadlines consistently met due to the account team’s excellent organization, diligence and coordination.   
 
- Perseverance: This deal cycle was 20 months from end to end.  Josh never let the fact that Cybereason were heavily invested in AWS, and had also decided to move significant workloads to GCP, deter him in his pursuit.  He strategically targeted the right teams within Cybereason, and though they kept changing, he was eventually able to raise the level of his engagement in the account. Josh’s perseverance and consistent execution powered this deal.
WINSTORY_USECASE: OCI - Cybersecurity, End Point Security

WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
Leverage Subject Matter Experts:  The coverage team realized that the only way to advance the deal meaningfully, and “unstall” conversations was to leverage numerous subject matter experts, including the OCI A-team in Romania.  Opening up these resources to the right people at the right time was critical to landing the deal. 
 
• Capitalizing on Tactical and Strategic Opportunities:  While the deal was initially focused on the larger prize of re-architecting A10’s on-prem load balancer solution into a LBaaS (for launch in 2QFY21), the team saw an immediate revenue opportunity that was in both Oracle’s and A10’s best interests, and capitalized on it. 
 
• Persistence: Oracle was tenacious in getting the deal done, and ensured that ideas were translated into revenue generating activities.  In addition, the team was very agile, managing pandemic and technical challenges effectively, and refused to let extraneous variables threaten the opportunity at hand.

WINSTORY_NAME: Thomson Reuters: ADB on ExaCC
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER:
TR has a strategic mandate to move all applications to the cloud, and get out of the datacenter business. About five years ago, due to human errors, costly hardware refreshes, and personnel expenses, they concluded to stop investing in data centers, consolidate their operations, and start moving things to the cloud. 
 
But Thomson Reuters had tens – if not hundreds – of millions of licensing agreements with their users preventing them from simply moving everything at once. Ideally Oracle would manage the cloud on-premises until Thomson Reuters could phase out these restrictive contracts and fully commit to OCI.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: Oracle worked closely with Thomson Reuters (TR) over four years developing what would become a leading enterprise-class service. After testing and approving Autonomous, TR challenged Oracle to make ADB available as a C@C service.  Since this was not yet available at the time of the sale, many contractual protections were required to de-risk the transaction for TR.  In addition, TR required that the entire solution, including data protection and migrations, be offered as a managed service.  This meant coordinating with OCS and ACS to develop a comprehensive package to deliver a fully managed cloud offering on TR’s premises.
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
1.  As we transform from a software and hardware company to a cloud services provider, there will be new and unique challenges in every large cloud deal.  
Executive engagement and buy-in is critical with deals of this size and complexity.  Without all stakeholders on board, there is simply no way we could have gotten past the many “one-off” requests and “first time for Oracle” terms.  
2. Patience and Perseverance.  These transactions are a marathon not a sprint.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: In addition to greatly reduced cost of infrastructure, TR will now be able to consume IT resources elastically, paying only for what they use.  More strategically, TR is now on the path to having an entirely third-party-managed solution, from their databases to their networking and virtualization.  That will give them the freedom to shift their focus to where it matters most: innovation, development, and customer service.
WINSTORY_USECASE: Migrate  Mission-Critical Apps to Autonomous, First ADB on ExaCC win

WINSTORY_NAME: Jopari: Path to OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
Collaborative Approach: This was a very complex process that, “took a village” to complete.  It required Benny Albert, Ash Hanhan, Dave Profozich, numerous members of the SC team and multiple Product Management resources to land this deal.  Look to leverage the deep expertise found across the entirety of the Oracle network.  
 
 Leverage Internal Champions:  The VP of Engineering’s role was critical.  He was the driving force on Jopari’s side, which made a big difference:  Azure had many healthcare case-studies. Oracle did not.  For this reason, quite a few senior people at Jopari favored Azure.  Helped by the VP of Engineering’s guidance, though, Jopari ultimately chose Oracle. 
 
 Build Trust:  This deal was signed on trust.  Ash established a baseline, having sold them Prop Hosting licenses several years prior.  Benny built on this and also managed to turn Jopari’s VP of Engineering into a powerful evangelist.  Critically, it was Jopari’s trust in Dave Profozich and his personal assurances that led them to sign the deal.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_USECASE: Path to OCI

WINSTORY_NAME: Vertex: OCi - Indirect Tax software
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Read the Win Wire on the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: Read the Win Wire on the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
Quantify results: The coverage team consistently and conservatively quantified what moving to OCI could mean for Vertex; showing impact numerically is very, very powerful – not just in terms of potential cost reduction, but opportunities to grow revenues as well. 
 
 Executive Sponsorship:  Without strong leadership buy-in on the partner’s side, the deal might not have happened.  In fact, Vertex were quite far along with their migration to AWS when Oracle took the bull by the horns.   
 
 Selling All of Oracle: A big component of the deal was selling the entirety of Oracle Cloud and the integration with our SaaS portfolio.  Autonomous Database featured here too.  The team demonstrated what Oracle Cloud services and capabilities could mean for every aspect of Vertex’s business.  The “hook” wasn’t just OCI, but rather Oracle. 
 
 Partnership as investment:  Kevin and Joe reframed the discussion from “cutting costs” to jointly investing and driving net new business.  This consistent repositioning of the partnership fundamentally changed how Vertex viewed Oracle.

WINSTORY_NAME: TMEIC: OAC & ADW for Analytical Workloads
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: TMEIC’s Director of IT came to us with concerns about the structure of their environment. The previous Oracle rep had incorrectly combined OMCS and UCC, so they were being charged an incredible amount for unused credits. The customer was upset and didn’t know how to use our Cloud or what they were paying for.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: The ECA and Hub team got boots on the ground – building out use cases from scratch and finding new opportunities with great growth options. They found that the customer was in dire need of more sophisticated analytics and had multiple sources to pull from. We went in and built a BOM then negotiated with the Director of IT to find a mutually beneficial starting point to get the deal closed in Q4. We closed a $209k contract for OAC and ADW. The customer is well underway with implementation and the new contract is far more friendly to the customer with great growth opportunity.

WINSTORY_NAME: Mastercard: Integrating MasterCard Send Platform to Oracle Cloud SaaS App
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: We began this journey middle of last year discussing integrating MasterCard Send Platform to Oracle Cloud SaaS apps.  Middle of February,  this project pivoted quickly to addressing payment from Governments/NGO’s as part of all the Covid Reflief State, Local, NonProfits were securing.  MC saw the issues of having trouble getting money into the hands of citizens quick and securely,  problem they wanted to solve.  We first partnered with Mastercard for the City of LA, partnering with John Sasson of the S&L CX team.  John’s team’s ability to stand up a CX solution quickly was a big help in convincing MasterCard that we were the right partner to go to market in developing this Disbursement Solution.  We got a lot of help from Nishanth Sodum (ECA) and the OCS team, although they did not go with OCS in the end, John Sasson and Peter Sills (CX PM).   Fred Riley (Cloud GVP) kept in close contact with the project owner/SrExec and helped guide the customer on their various iterations of this project.  As with all things related to Covid, it was a bumpy ride but the whole team stayed focused on moving this forward to completion.
WINSTORY_USECASE: Autonomous DB as well as other cloud services to develop a disbursement portal

WINSTORY_NAME: Ericom:OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
Perseverance: This deal cycle was almost 20 months from end to end and Josh was told “no” twice.  Josh never let these initial set-backs deter him.  When he learned of the 8x8 win, Josh saw his opportunity and capitalized on it.  Josh’s perseverance and consistent execution powered this deal. 
 
 White Glove Treatment: From the beginning, Josh supported Ericom with their journey to the cloud and cultivated strong relationships with their founder and C-suite.  That they chose AWS initially did not stop Josh from building ever-deeper bonds.  And, when Ericom finally wanted to conduct a POC on OCI the outstanding technical service that Baba Shaik and Pete Schaffer provided sealed the deal. 
 
 Leveraging Previous Wins – Success breeds success.  Josh capitalized on the momentum OCI is gaining and used it to remove a barrier he had been facing.  He also astutely reframed the cost discussion into one centered on price-performance, highlighting how OCI not only offered a more economical service versus other clouds, but also how our highly-performant infrastructure could meet their sub-100 millisecond latency requirements.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: Read the Win Wire in the Collateral Tab

WINSTORY_NAME: Arterra Wines: Migrate Custom Oracle DB Apps to Cloud
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Customer was using OCI-Classic and was experiencing performance issues
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS:
Arterra was using OCI Classic in Chicago for their JDE, App servers, and the ExaCS in Ashburn.  
All processes were working; however, the performance did not meet the customer’s expectations. 

They were experiencing a lot of challenges with their classic environment and were considering of moving to Microsoft Azure. 

The accounts team with the help of Product Managers and solution engineers conducted series of meetings with the IT Team and interview with the business to understand the technical issues and problems experiencing by the users. 

After the meetings, we identified the solutions that can resolve issues and presented a plan to the customer on how we could provide them a much better performance with lesser disruption to the business compared to moving to Microsoft.
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT:
My advice is with this kind of project, the sales team should engage OCS on the early stage of sales cycle. 
You should have an open and honest communication with the customers especially the decision makers. 
It helps in managing the expectation and cuts the unnecessary objections once the proposal is presented. 
And lastly, make sure to include trainings in your implementation plan to ensure customer success.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT:
•	Lower overall costs with greater value - more resilient and reliable OCI platform for networking and ExaCS operations 
•	Greater option to control budget and desired spending limits within departments for GIS application business owners 
•	Spending $102K per month which was considerably more than the expected spend

WINSTORY_NAME: City of Jackson: Lift and Shift CC&B application to OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: The City of Jackson uses Oracle CC&B application for their primary revenue generating ability for the utility department. However, they were having issues in maintaining and managing the application on-premise resulting in an overwhelming utility bill collection backlog. Their hardware refresh cycle has reached its end of life, and the lack of current functional resources to manage the application in-house has forced them to opt for an outsourcing model.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: The customer was currently speaking to AWS and a local hosting service provider to host their application. Since the utility department was in debt due to their inability to bill their citizens and collect a payment, they were extremely price sensitive. However, the more significant challenge was the functional expertise that they needed for the CC&B application. We offered a complete solution of hosting the application and providing technical enhancements in partnership with Mythics.
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT: Understanding and solving customer business problems is the key to winning strategic deals.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: The customer has agreed to lift the entire production and non-production CC&B systems to OCI. As part of the move, Mythics will fix the broken business process, integration, and patch the system. The customer has signed a three-year contract of $950K, including the consulting piece. The second phase of the project will be the CC&B upgrade during the end of this calendar year.
WINSTORY_USECASE: Lift and Shift CC&B application to OCI

WINSTORY_NAME: US Department of Education: OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: The Department of Education identified critical security weaknesses in the areas of user identification and authentication, data encryption, logging and auditing, and physical access.  Following the Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management (FICAM) initiative, Education determined the need modernize their existing ad-hoc approach to Identity & Access Management with an Enterprise level strategy/solution.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS:
In 2018 & 2019, the Department of Education purchased Oracle's Enterprise Identity Services Suite licenses to support their Security Modernization efforts.   Mythics Consulting was contracted to build a comprehensive IDM solution for the Department, with customer's goal to deploy the solution on IBM's cloud based on an existing IBM contract.   The initial phase of the ICAM deployment was expected to support approximately 8,000 users but anticipated to grow to as many as 25 mil. users once the solution was expanded to non-ED users (Federal Student Aid contractors & other FSA users).   
 
After several missed milestones and technical hurdles working with the IBM cloud, project stakeholders reached out to Mythics Consulting in March, 2020 seeking an alternative cloud solution.   Through numerous meetings/calls with Education, Mythics and Oracle were able to successfully present and scope an alternative solution that gave Education confidence it could scale as necessary.    This OCI Cloud deal is a direct win from the competition (IBM).
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: By moving to an enterprise solution, Education was able to lower operational costs, avoid disparities in security enforcement & management, improve interoperability across Education products and services while reducing the duplication of multiple investments that address common business functions.
WINSTORY_USECASE: OCI foundation to run previously contracted Oracle IDM solution supporting 8K users with anticipated growth to 25M users.

WINSTORY_NAME: McLaren Healthcare: IDCS in OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: McLaren is moving their on-prem PeopleSoft to OCI and needed mulit-factor authentication for the environment. Back in 2019, they were victims of a phishing security breech that required more stringent security measures to be put in place.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: ACS reached out to discuss McLaren’s issue with their current authentication service- DUO.  Although DUO is used hospital wide and therefor needed to stay in place, it was causing problems with their business critical PeopleSoft environment.  After further investigation, we found that IDCS was the solution that would eliminate the issues as McLaren prepares to move to OCI.
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT: Developing a relationship with the CIO was imperative so that we could stay in communication during the process.  We are now exploring other areas within the hospital that may benefit from OCI.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: McLaren will be able to keep their hospital-wide 2-factor authentication in place, while IDCS will allow for innovation to OCI, which will in-turn save McLaren a significant amount of money as they migrate out of the data center.
WINSTORY_USECASE: IDCS in OCI

WINSTORY_NAME: TIAA: OCI Expansion
WINSTORY_REPS_SE: Heidi.Hoppenfeld@oracle.com, Eric.Rinehart@oracle.com, Shahnawaz.Khan@oracle.com, Ken.Leigh@oracle.com, Joel.Stambaugh@oracle.com, David.Nosal@oracle.com, Malcom.DeMayo@oracle.com, Michael.Giordano@oracle.com
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Oracle provided a more cost-efficient, secure and higher-performance solution then AWS
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS:
- The Cloud and Analytics team worked with TIAA global corporate solutions and technology team to perform a current state/ future state/ gap analysis effort
- Prioritized projects and workloads based on clients budget and resource availability
- Developed high-level implementation plan to show month by month usage 
- Created business benefit and cost analysis of BAU vs new structured Cloud agreement
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT: Making sure the client received value from the previous cloud purchase was critical before we could suggest expansion. There were no shortcuts in the due diligence process. TIAA teams were siloed with poor internal communication so Oracle became source of truth throughout the process. Leveraging Oracle internal resources & technical SME’s was critical for solution design and credibility with TIAA networking & security teams.
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT:
- Hybrid architecture to support SaaS, IaaS and On-premise workloads 
- 40% cost savings vs on-premise
- Shift from on-premise analytics to OAC lowers cost, increases time to value and expands user capabilities
- Lower cost allows TIAA to quickly migrate smaller unplanned workloads 
- OIC replacing Mulesoft and custom ETLs for simplified data integration standard
- TIAA enterprise data office evaluating OAC for OBIEE, Tableau and Alteryx replacement
WINSTORY_USECASE: FY20 Move Workloads to IaaS & PaaS

WINSTORY_NAME: Fire Department of NY: OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: The FDNY expansion is part of a long term strategy to build new applications in the cloud and move existing onprem applications to the cloud. To date FDNY has deployed 9 applications on OCI including 2 that are mission critical and used directly by first responders. Incident Command is used by the commanding officer at the site of the emergency to track and coordinate all resources and activities – it is very sophisticated and comprehensive. Accident Reporting is used to automate/expedite the of recording  pertinent information when a fire truck is involved in an accident. Both are mobile applications used by the first responders so performance, availability and security are of critical importance. They were built using a couple of different cloud services including database, mobile and a few 3rd party technologies all running on OCI. Next initiative is to create a DR environment in the Phoenix Data Center.
WINSTORY_USECASE: Build Low Code Apps, Oracle DB Custom App Migrations and Consolidation, HA/DR for Business Continuity, Move Workloads to IaaS & PaaS

WINSTORY_NAME: J.P. Morgan Chase: Delivers  Open Banking Treasury Solution  with Oracle Cloud (OIC)
WINSTORY_REPS_SE: John.Hayden@oracle.com, Kyle.Gerstner@oracle.com, Marie.Cabrera@oracle.com, Sanjay.Mathew@oracle.com, Stu.Sugarman@oracle.com, Marty.Pattwell@oracle.com, Lynn.Wu@oracle.com, Vijaya Vishwanath@oracle.com
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: A growing industry trend, open banking allows corporate customers to seamlessly integrate with treasury and payment services without the need to log in to bank systems.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: JPMC’s preference of AWS as a cloud platform was an obstacle. Key Account Director Marty Pattwell and Industry Advisor Stu Sugarman leveraged their deep knowledge of JPMC’s existing architecture to make a compelling case for Oracle Cloud. The Oracle team met regularly with their managing directors and eventually the CIO about HCM to successfully onboard 250,000 employees, so we'd proven ourselves as a trusted collaborator. The team invested heavily in a PoC with strong support from Oracle Solution Engineering and the Oracle Treasurer’s office, which acted as a pilot customer. They brought in Lynn Wu and Vijaya Vishwanath from Oracle North America Solutions HUB and Marie Cabrera for executive alignment. Their combined efforts resulted in a move to procurement only four weeks into the eight-week PoC, and Systems Integrator Risk Focus is onboard to ensure the rollout is a success.

WINSTORY_NAME: Sephora: Moves DB to OCI
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Sephora needed to get out of their DC and keep performance high between app and DB tiers.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS:
•	Sephora was looking to renew the DB licenses and run them in Azure.
	The Oracle On-prem team proposed OCI for the DBs and set up an SE led trial for the customer
	They then informed the me of Sephora’s use case
•	ECAs and Cloud engineers worked with Sephora on the trial. The initial results were great.
	The trial rapidly turned into a POC / pilot to production
•	With continuous support from the cloud team, we proved out all success criteria and moved forward with issuing ODs
•	We proceeded with pricing negotiations at the C-level and finally came to a mutual agreement  
•	The OD was signed one day before quarter end
•	We immediately converted the trial to a paid subscription gaining that consumption instantly
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT: Repeatable steps: Regular cadence with customers engaged in a POC. If not, the deal would have slipped to Q1
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: The specific apps (Oracle ATG & IBM OMS) run Sephora’s e-commerce platform. Due to the Covid pandemic their e-commerce site made up 100% of their revenue. Hence, performance / latency between the e-commerce apps and respective DBs was (and still is) critical.
WINSTORY_USECASE: Move Workloads to IaaS & PaaS - DB move to OCI

WINSTORY_NAME: Specialized Bicycles: Soaring to OCI with One Oracle
WINSTORY_REPS_SE: Rishi Popat@oracle.com, Shaun.Karamdashti@oracle.com, Tanvi.Kotibhaskar@oracle.com, Santosh.Kumar.Ramarathnam@oracle.com, Vinod.Lakshminarayanasw@oracle.com, Trey.Parson@oracle.com, Bryan.Emig@oracle.com, George.Saade@oracle.com, Jordan. Fier@oracle.com, Jesse.Niedringhaus@oracle.com, Danny.Dunn@oracle.com, Philip.Papadopoulos@oracle.com, Ashwini.Tansalker@oracle.com, Naavica.Adunur@oracle.com,  Robert.Meade@oracle.com,  Gerhard.Scherffel@oracle.com,  Mohammad.Hasan@oracle.com, Angel.Calder@oracle.com
WINSTORY_BUSSINESS_DRIVER: Besides the modernization to address end-of-life hardware, performance enhancements, and disaster recovery with OCI, Specialized was interested in the scalability the Cloud could offer to achieve their growth goal: doubling their business in the next five years, which is unattainable with their on-premises environment. Specialized forecasts expansion in the electric bicycle space to boost their sales.
WINSTORY_SALES_PROCESS: Once Consulting proved out that EBS could be migrated, Consulting Solution Directors and the Cloud Architect team got to work on the plan to migrate Specialized’s Agile environment with 72 integrations. After reviewing the bill of materials, current and future state architectures, and factoring in the Soar methodology, we were confident in our proposal.The tempo of the sales cycle slowed with COVID-19. The CIO was let go and Team Oracle thought this potential contract was headed downhill. A new CIO was appointed and the account team built an immediate relationship. The CIO became committed to advancing the project with one major concern: the effectiveness of a 100% remote delivery during a shutdown.
WINSTORY_LESSON_LEARNT: One Oracle
WINSTORY_CUSTOMER_IMPACT: The scalability the Cloud could offer to achieve their growth goal: doubling their business in the next five years, which is unattainable with their on-premises environment. Specialized forecasts expansion in the electric bicycle space to boost their sales
WINSTORY_USECASE: Soar EBS and Agile Cross-Platform Migration
